name: West Caucasian Ibex
description: It has brown-gray fur, dark legs, and males have a short beard. The horns are arched and prominently notched, up to 75 cm long in males and shorter in females.
spread_note: Small area in the western Caucasus, at elevations of 800–4,500 m
image_alt: West Caucasian Ibex, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 130–140 cm; tail length 12–15 cm; shoulder height 60–85 cm; weight 50–120 kg
attractions: They climb steep rocky cliffs with incredible confidence, and even newborns can follow their mothers within about two hours of birth. Their hooves are adapted for rocky terrain—sharp-edged yet slightly flexible, with a slightly concave sole creating a suction effect, like a rubber cup on glass, while the soft inner part adheres to the rock surface. Ibexes are extremely vigilant. Note their pupils—horizontal slits providing a wide field of vision.
breeding: Ibexes have been kept at Prague Zoo almost continuously since 1976.
